docs.lead_paragraph: A Federal jury awarded $786,257 to three waitresses who accused their bosses of discrimination for claiming they were ''too fat'' to work while pregnant. ''I feel I've really done right by all women, not just myself and the other girls,'' said Barbara Nuesse, who was dismissed after her fifth month of pregnancy.

headline.main: National News Briefs; Waitresses Get Award In Discrimination Case

docs.abstract: Jury in Fort Launderdale, Fla, orders Rustic Inn Crabhouse to pay $786,257 to three waitresses who were told they were 'too fat' to work while pregnant (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: An outbreak of rubella, a once-common disease that standard vaccinations have rendered all but obsolete among Americans, is spreading among Hispanic immigrants in Westchester and Fairfield Counties. Since Dec. 19, 22 cases have been confirmed in both counties and 24 others are suspected. Health officials in Westchester and Connecticut have begun immunization drives aimed at adults from Central and South America, where the vaccination is not standard.

headline.main: Rubella Outbreak Hits Hispanic Immigrant Communities

docs.abstract: Outbreak of rubella is spreading among Hispanic immigrants in Westchester and Fairfield Counties; health officials in both counties have begun immunization drives aimed at adults from Central and South America, where vaccination is not standard; disease is all but obsolete among native-born Americans, who have received standard vaccinations; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It has been nine years since C. Everett Koop has worn the uniform of the Surgeon General of the United States, yet he calculates that in some months, he spends 30 percent of his time talking to Americans about smoking, nutrition, exercise and so on -- ''the kinds of things,'' he said in a recent interview, ''that a Surgeon General really ought to be doing.'' But no Surgeon General has been doing them, because for the past three years there has been no Surgeon General. Dr. Joycelyn Elders, the last person to hold the job, was dismissed by President Clinton after making impolitic comments about masturbation. Dr. Henry W. Foster Jr., an obstetrician, was named to succeed her, but his nomination foundered when he acknowledged having performed abortions.

headline.main: Job Itself in Doubt As New Feud Looms On Surgeon General

docs.abstract: Fracas over Dr David Satcher, Pres Clinton's latest nominee for Surgeon General, leads some to wonder if post, vacant for three years, should be eliminated; public health experts and most politicians say nation needs top public health official, but role often collides with public mores on hot-button issues (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: This is the moment when, in my dreams, I begin to cry. And yet, I'm strangely calm as I go up the stairs to the apartment of my childhood in Santos Suarez, the only place that, after all these years, I still refer to as la casa, home. I am holding a pen and a reporter's notebook in my hand and, as I always do when I am working, I count the steps: 20. In my memory, there were only 16. The staircase seems narrower than I remember, the ceiling lower.

headline.main: Havana Journal; A Sentimental Journey To La Casa of Childhood

docs.abstract: Mirta Ojito article on her return to Cuba as reporter to cover Pope John Paul II's visit; discusses her emotional return to house of her childhood in Santos Suarez; notes that she was 16 when she left Cuba with her parents during first days of Mariel boat lift in May 1980; says her home remains practically as they left it, seemingly frozen in time, like much of Cuba; map; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A bill that would require women seeking an abortion in New Jersey to meet with the physician at least 24 hours in advance has angered doctors and abortion rights supporters, who say that most women already consult with a doctor or counselor before going ahead with the procedure. Lawmakers who introduced the proposal last week said that the waiting period would encourage women to think about the procedure and consider other options. But most women already have to wait at least a week before having an abortion, doctors and pregnancy counselors said, because not many doctors perform the procedure. A mandatory waiting period would only add to the stigma surrounding abortion, they said.

headline.main: New Jersey Doctors Angered by Plan for Abortion Delay

docs.lead_paragraph: What I found truly newsworthy in your Sunday item ''Sex: Say No ... and Win!'' (Jan. 11) was not the use of cash incentives to discourage unwanted pregnancy but the unquestioned linkage of not wanting to be pregnant with not wanting to have sex. Indeed, if the crux of Gil Burnett's program is to convince young women to say no to sex, rather than to educate them about various forms of birth control, then the program is really about ''pleasure control.'' Of course, the program wants only women to be denied the pleasures of sex -- men are excluded. Steven Rubenstein Athens, Ohio
docs.abstract: Steven Rubenstein letter comments on Jan 11 article on Gil Burnett's program of cash incentives to discourage unwanted pregnancy; says focus should be on education about birth control rather than just saying no to sex (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: FIFTY years ago last month, the publication of Alfred C. Kinsey's ''Sexual Behavior in the Human Male'' had Americans agog over sex as never before. The name Kinsey was everywhere -- in newspapers, magazines and on the radio, ultimately turning into risque code in places as varied as nightclub acts and New Yorker cartoons. James H. Jones in his recent biography of the researcher (Norton, 1997) asserts that Kinsey was a secret masochist and a homosexual whose real agenda was to promote the acceptance of homosexuality. If that is true, he would be cheered by the changes in American attitudes since 1948.

headline.main: Just Say Maybe; No Sexology, Please. We're Americans

docs.abstract: Sexual research is still not really respectable in US fifty years after publication of Alfred Kinsey's report, reflecting longstanding American ambivalence about delicate subject; sqeamish or moralistic attitudes become most problematic with adolescents, who receive little practical sex education or guidance beyond warnings about disease (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The memories of his father's sudden death are absent because Ricky Ledee did not witness the fatal accident on a dark highway near Manati. He did not witness Tonito Ledee's car drifting into the oncoming lane after he fell asleep following another singing performance, did not see it rumbling down a hill and smashing into a truck. The collision destroyed the car and killed Ledee instantly. He was 35 years old. The memories Ricky has are not of the accident, but of what followed. How a 12-year-old boy was forced to turn from a brother into a father and from a young son into a young man. How his pregnant mother cried so often that friends worried it would damage the unborn child. How he escaped from the weeping by watching the horses graze near his house. How he declined to play baseball because it reminded him of his father.

headline.main: Waiting to See If This Is the Spring; For Yanks' Ledee, The Majors Beckon And a Death Haunts

docs.abstract: Ricky Ledee, 24-year-old left-field prospect for New York Yankees, awaits baseball's call this season at his home in Puerto Rico; photos (S)
